message: Roll Tide! What a great win today in Atlanta. Especially proud of Daphne High School's Ryan Anderson on being named defensive player of the game and his outstanding pick six!
Happy New Year from my family to yours! Looking forward to big things in 2017!
Severe weather is expected across Southwest Alabama today. I encourage everyone to pay attention to warnings and stay weather aware!

It is safe to say that John Kerry's tenure as Secretary of State has been a disaster. Now, in his last few days, he has decided to make attacking Israel his top priority. As Jim Geraghty puts it in this column, "The cement hardens on the Obama-Kerry foreign-policy legacy: They were toothless and hapless against ISIS, Bashar al-Assad, North Korea, Iran, Russia, China, and the world‚Äôs worst and most ruthless regimes. But as for Bibi Netanyahu, they came down on him like a ton of bricks."

I joined a number of local television stations this morning to preview the 115th Congress, which kicks off today. On Local 15 NBC News, WPMI Mobile, I talked about my opposition to efforts to change certain ethics organizations and the need to continue supporting the Austal shipyard in Mobile and the other shipyards along the Gulf Coast. We have plenty of work to do!

Illegal immigration continues to be a big issue. Figures from the Department of Homeland Security show a 15% surge in illegal border crossings. Just another example of the need to enforce our current immigration laws and get serious about securing the border.

I am now sworn in, and the 115th Congress is officially underway. I am very excited about the potential to make a real, positive impact on behalf of the American people. Our top priority should always be to focus on policies that benefit the American people. By doing that, I believe we can help restore faith in government and make life easier for all Americans.

I joined WKRG this morning to talk about some of the issues I hope Congress will address in the new year. We talked about repealing Obamacare, tackling illegal immigration, and the confirmation process for President-elect Trump's cabinet.

I reached out to a number of local officials today to pledge the help of my office as our communities clean up from yesterday's storms. My heart especially breaks for the Rehobeth community, near Dothan, where people were killed by the storms. I encourage all of us to continue praying for all of those impacted by the severe weather.

The train has left the station on trying to "fix" Obamacare.  It is fundamentally flawed and must be repealed. Without any Congressional action, the law will continue to implode. It would be irresponsible for Congress to do nothing while so many Americans are struggling with fewer health care choices, higher deductibles, and unaffordable plans.

I just introduced my first bill for the new 115th Congress: a Balanced Budget Amendment. I thought it was important and fitting for my first bill introduced to be a balanced budget amendment. With the national debt over $19 trillion dollars, it is no secret the federal government has serious spending issues, and I believe a balanced budget amendment is the best way to ensure responsible budgeting.

The House just passed the Midnight Rules Relief Act. This commonsense reform would allow Congress to overturn, with a single vote, regulations finalized in the last 60 days of an outgoing Presidential administration. As he heads out the door, President Obama continues to issue expensive regulations that hit Americans where it hurts: their pocketbooks. I'm pleased the bill passed by a vote of 238 to 184.

Today, I introduced a Balanced Budget Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Requiring balanced budgets is not a far flung idea. Already, most states are required to have a balanced budget, and families and small businesses face the challenge of living within their means every single day. The federal government should have to play by the same rules in order to restore fiscal sanity in Washington.

I got a little fired up on the House floor today while speaking in support of a resolution to condemn the Obama Administration for abstaining from a recent United Nations (UN) vote relating to Israel. In other words, the United States turned our back and looked the other way as the UN passed a flawed resolution attacking Israel. By abstaining and allowing this resolution to pass, the Obama Administration has upset decades of bipartisan policy as it relates to Israel and put a pathway to peace between Israel and the Palestinian Authority even further out of reach. I think supporting Israel is a cause worth fighting for, and I was pleased to see over 340 of my colleagues joining me in a strong bipartisan vote in support of Israel.

I was pleased with Speaker Ryan's announcement yesterday that a provision to defund Planned Parenthood will be included in our Obamacare repeal bill. The actions taken by Planned Parenthood are reprehensible, and they should not receive a single penny of federal funding. Instead, that money should go toward community health centers, which provide critical health services to women without also providing abortion services.

I'm proud to be included on this list of Members of Congress pushing for a repeal and replacement of Obamacare. Obamacare was built on a bunch of lies, and now it is our job to try and make things right for the American people. We can't simply do nothing and allow this law to continue collapsing while American families suffer.
I enjoyed catching up with Navy Secretary Ray Mabus and Commandant of the Marine Corps Robert Neller today at the Marine Barracks for Secretary Mabus' farewell tribute.

Despite the efforts of some House Democrats to cause a stir and delay the process, Congress today officially certified the Electoral College results. One member of Congress even tried to challenge Alabama's nine electoral votes saying that Russia changed the results in our state. That shows just how far they are willing to go to question the clear results of the Electoral College process.

I have continually asked for a classified briefing regarding Russia's recent hacking activity, but so far, no such briefing has been given. It is common in situations like this for the intelligence community to brief Congress on their findings in a classified setting, so I am growing more frustrated by the day as information is leaked to the media before Congress gets a briefing.

Today is National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day! It is easy to take for granted the dangerous and difficult work our police officers do on a daily basis. From call to call, they have no idea what to expect or what threats might come next. Tonight, I will be displaying the blue light below in the window of my Congressional office in Washington, D.C. as a sign of support for our law enforcement officers. It is my prayer that God continue to bless and watch over all of our police officers.
My fellow The University of Alabama graduates on my D.C. staff were decked out in their crimson and white today. Who else is rooting on the Tide tonight? #RollTide #NationalChampionship
I'm live on C-SPAN's Washington Journal this morning talking about Jeff Sessions and what a great Attorney General he will be. We will also be taking your questions, so be sure to tune in!

Jeff Sessions is a true gentleman and an ethical leader. It is so frustrating to see some try to attack his character just to advance their political agenda. I joined C-SPAN's Washington Journal this morning to talk about the real Jeff Sessions. A man who helped bring down the KKK in Alabama. A man who fought public corruption in Mobile. A man who supports our nation's law enforcement officers. A man who stands up for the rule of law. Despite what some may want you to believe, Jeff Sessions is a great man and will be an outstanding Attorney General.

Very pleased to see the hostage situation in Tuscaloosa come to an end without any injuries. This is a testament to the great work of our local law enforcement officials. I hope you will join me in praying for all those shaken up by this traumatic experience.

This afternoon, the House passed an important, bipartisan bill to help our nation's startups and small businesses. This bill is necessary because government regulations have had the unintended consequence of limiting opportunity to raise capital. These startups could have the ability to change the world, and they shouldn't be negatively impacted by unnecessary government bureaucracy.

This morning, I had the opportunity to speak at the Surface Navy Association's 29th Annual Symposium. I explained why there is no greater responsibility of the federal government than providing for our national defense, and that includes a strong and fully capable Navy. In fact, Article One of our Constitution grants Congress the power to ‚Äúraise‚Äù an Army when needed, but directs Congress to ‚Äúprovide and maintain a Navy.‚Äù

As the debate over health care continues, let us not forget the most important fact: Obamacare has failed. Costs have skyrocketed, including an average increase of 22% this year. Approximately 4.7 million Americans were kicked off their health plans. Fewer health care options exist, including only one health insurance provider in five states. We can't just keep doing the same thing and expect something to change. We must repeal Obamacare and replace it with something that actually works.

It really is a small world! While at the Surface Navy Association's National Symposium today, I ran into Coast Guard Commander Phillip Crigler. He is a Mobile native and graduate of Baker High School. It is always fun to run into people from Southwest Alabama in our nation's capital.

The Senate has taken the first step in the process of repealing Obamacare, and I expect the House will act in the next few days. Due to procedural roadblocks from Democrats, we are having to use a multi-step process in order to get the repeal passed. In reality, the ultimate outcome, not procedure, is what is important. We must get rid of this failed law and replace it with something that actually works.

It was great to visit with 8th graders from St. Paul's Episcopal School today. They have been in Washington over the past week to learn more about our nation's government. I was able to answer some of their questions about our work in Congress before posing for a photo in front of the United States Capitol.

Very exciting news for our area! Mobile will be one of 15 cities across the United States selected to host a "Navy Week." This will include a port visit from the USS Mason, an Arleigh Burke-class destroyer. Navy Week will coincide with Mardi Gras, so it will be a very exciting time for Southwest Alabama!

Today, the House is scheduled to vote on a resolution helping pave the way for the repeal of Obamacare. Due to procedural roadblocks in the Senate, we are having to go through a multi-step process in order to get the repeal bill to the President's desk. This chart helps explain the process, and today the House will act on step number 3. We are going through a thoughtful process to ensure we get this right.

BIG NEWS: The House just passed the first step in our effort to repeal Obamacare. Over the last few years, Republicans around the country have campaigned on repealing Obamacare and instead moving forward with patient-centered health care reforms that lower costs for American families. Today‚Äôs vote was an important first step in that process. It is important to remember that this will be a multi-step process, but Congress must act. Obamacare is imploding before our eyes. Premiums have skyrocketed, deductibles are unaffordable, and patients have fewer and fewer health care options. This process is about addressing those issues and bringing real relief to the American people.

I'm honored to be named Chairman of the Subcommittee on Workforce Protections. Over the last eight years, there has been an effort to fundamentally change the way we deal with labor and employment issues. These changes have largely reduced opportunities for advancement and weakened the standing of American workers. My goal will be to right the ship in favor of policies that benefit workers across our country and empower them to succeed.

Yesterday, the House passed a bill providing an important waiver to allow General James Mattis to serve as Secretary of Defense. As I thought about General Mattis, I decided to pull out my copy of Meditations by the great Roman Emperor, Marcus Aurelius, which General Mattis' favorite book. If you have read Meditations, you would know the writings teach the importance of humility by telling the story of leaders spending time with the warriors on the front lines. That is something General Mattis has always demonstrated throughout his service to our nation. And I have great confidence that he knows that that is where the strength of our military lies.

This bust of Martin Luther King, Jr. sits in the Rotunda of the U.S. Capitol building. I think it is fitting that a man who had such a profound impact on our country is highlighted in one of our nation's most iconic buildings. As we celebrate his life today, may we remember one of his most memorable quotes: "Our lives begin to end the day we become silent about things that matter."
Preparations continue on the West Front of the Capitol as we prepare for Friday's Inauguration ceremony.

I enjoyed taking part in the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr 28th Annual Memorial Breakfast at Bishop State Community College this morning. It is always such a great event to honor the lasting impact of Dr. King.
Very exciting news for Monroe County!

I enjoyed speaking to leaders from the Coastal Alabama Partnership and Coastal Gateway Regional Economic Development Alliance today in Monroeville. I talked about ways Congress can help support retail in our local communities.

This decision is great news for Alabama's farmers! Being from Georgia, I know Governor Perdue is very familiar with our southern commodities, especially considering the fact he was raised on a farm and is a graduate of the University of Georgia College of Veterinary Medicine. Agriculture remains the top industry in Alabama, and I look forward to working with Sonny Perdue to continue supporting our farmers and foresters.

Glad my office could provide Inauguration tickets to so many families from Southwest Alabama. Regardless of your political views, tomorrow is an important day because it represents the peaceful transition of power, and that is something we should all take great pride in. Tomorrow is going to be an exciting day for our country!

Such an exciting day for America! I thought President Trump's Inauguration speech touched on a number of important issues including rebuilding our infrastructure, making things easier for American workers, building up our military, restoring the rule of law, and growing our economy. Now it is time to get to work!

Earlier today, I took some cookies to our fantastic Capitol Police officers as a small token of my appreciation for their hard work. We should be especially thankful for all the law enforcement officers who worked hard to keep the Inauguration ceremonies safe and secure.

This is a really cool story! Marine Major Christopher Lyon piloted the helicopter that took former President Obama from the U.S. Capitol to Joint Base Andrews after the Inauguration. Chris is from Mobile and a graduate of McGill-Toolen. He is also friends with my son, Patrick, dating back to their time in Boy Scouts.

No child should remain stuck in a failing school. That is why I am proud to support #SchoolChoice. And, let me be clear, this isn't a binary choice between supporting public schools or being for school choice. I am proud of our nation's public schools and will continue advocating for their success. This is about ensuring that every child has the opportunity to be successful. That is something we should all be able to agree on.

Are you having issues with a federal agency like Social Security or Medicare? Are you a veteran struggling with the bureaucracy at the VA?  If so, I encourage you to seek help from my staff. Members of my team will be holding "Community Office Hours" this week in each of the six counties that make up Alabama's First Congressional District. Today they will be in Grove Hill, Jackson, Atmore, Flomaton, Brewton, East Brewton, Monroeville, and Chatom. You can see the full schedule at the link below.

The deadline to apply for a summer internship in my D.C. and Mobile offices is quickly approaching. These internships are an excellent opportunity to college students to learn more about the legislative process and gain first-hand work experience. You can learn more about the internships and apply here: https://byrne.house.gov/services/internships

HAPPENING NOW: The House just passed an important pro-life bill! I voted in favor of the legislation, which would permanently ban taxpayer funding of abortion. The bill passed by a vote of 238 to 183. I am proud to stand up for life and continue supporting pro-life policies.

President Trump‚Äôs actions have show that he is committed to following through with exactly what he said he would do. Whether it is his institution of a federal hiring freeze, attempt to move the Keystone XL pipeline project forward, efforts to ease the burden of Obamacare, or support for pro-life policies that ensure taxpayer money isn‚Äôt used for abortions, President Trump is off to a solid start.
Day 1 Recap from GOP Retreat in Philadelphia

You may have seen some news reports about the I-10 Bridge project not being included on a reported "transportation projects list" of the Trump Administration. As soon as we heard about the situation, my office reached out to the new staff at the federal Department of Transportation to emphasize the need for the I-10 Bridge. We have been reassured they are aware of the project and that the project list is not final or comprehensive. I believe our efforts have succeeded in assuring the I-10 bridge will be on the final list.  I appreciate the quick response of the Trump Administration when we brought this problem to their attention.
As Mobile prepares to host the Senior Bowl once again this weekend, Mobile Bay Magazine takes an interesting look at the history of Ladd-Peebles Stadium. Worth a read!

Appreciate President Donald J. Trump taking the time to share his agenda and plans during the House and a Senate GOP retreat. It is important we work together to advance our shared goals and priorities.
It was an honor to meet British Prime Minister Theresa May today. I look forward to doing my part to strengthen the relationship between our two countries.

Looking forward to the Senior Bowl tomorrow! Not only do we have the honor of hosting the game in Mobile, but Alabama and Auburn have sent the most players over the years to this all-star game.  Can't say that I'm surprised!   http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2017/01/which_colleges_have_sent_the_m.html#0

As a proud father, I have been blessed with the opportunity to watch each of my four children grow into successful and intelligent men and women.  Every child deserves that chance.  Thank you to everybody who participated in The March for Life today, especially those who traveled from Southwest Alabama!

Our military is suffering from a very real and serious readiness crisis. I applaud President Trump for instructing Secretary of Defense Mattis to conduct a full readiness review of our military. Peace through strength is a key component of a strong and successful foreign policy strategy.

President Trump announced this morning that he will eliminate two regulations for every one new regulation. I think this is a major step in the right direction as we fight to cut through red tape. The people hurt most by regulations are small businesses, who don't have the legal and compliance teams necessary to comply with and understand many of these regulations. By cutting back on rules and regulations, our small businesses will better be able to grow, and the overall economic climate will improve.

Tomorrow is the deadline to apply for a summer internship in my Washington D.C. or Mobile office. These interships are an excellent oppurtunity for college students to gain valuable real world work experience while also learning more about the legislative process. You can apply or learn more about the internships here: https://byrne.house.gov/services/internships

There is a lot of misinformation and overreaction out there regarding President Trump's actions to keep the American people safe, so I wanted to share the actual text of the executive order with you. I think much of the noise about these actions has been caused by the mainstream media overreacting. Despite what some may be reporting, the reform is not a "Muslim ban." There are over 40 majority Muslim countries not included in the restrictions. In fact, the executive order doesn't set any sort of religious test for being allowed into the United States. Instead, this is about keeping the American people safe and ensuring we have a process to adequately vet people entering the United States from certain countries that pose a high risk.   This is also a measured approach. Consider these numbers: On Saturday, 325,000 people from foreign countries came into the United States and 109 people were detained for further questioning. There is not the widespread issues that the national news media wants you to believe. Instead, this is a very thoughtful approach to keeping the American people safe.

I recently joined a number of my House colleagues in calling on President Trump to fire IRS Commissioner John Koskinen. I strongly believe Commissioner Koskinen withheld information from Congress regarding the IRS targeting of conservative non-profits, and he should be replaced with an IRS Commissioner who will respect Congress and our nation's laws.

I went to the floor of the House today to remember the life of a proud Mobilian, Lewis Odom Jr. Lewis lived a life many strive to emulate; a life filled with purpose, integrity, and selfless commitment to those around him. He had such a genuine impact on my life and the lives of so many others. As a young lawyer, Lewis was a mentor to me. He taught me the very import life lesson of choosing your battles wisely. From his first days in Mobile to his last, Lewis was ever present in the community, serving in any way he could, always giving of his time and devotion. During his years in Mobile, Lewis served as a chairman on the Alabama Ethics Commission, chairman of the Mobile Water Board, Chancellor of the Episcopal Diocese of the Central Gulf Coast, and chairman of the Mobile Museum Board. He was a great man, and he will be sorely missed.
I think this is an excellent pick! Judge Gorsuch understands and believes in the rule of law. I hope the Senate will act swiftly to confirm him.

I want to congratulate all the young athletes from Southwest Alabama who signed a scholarship offer today. In addition to these students, I also want to congratulate their parents and coaches for the important role they played in the process. Best of luck to each of you!

I enjoyed hosting Mobile County Commissioner Jerry Carl and Pastor Fred Wolfe from Luke 4:18 Fellowship as my guests for this morning's National Prayer Breakfast. It is always great to spend the morning in prayer for our country and our leaders.

I enjoyed hosting some of my fellow Episcopalian Members of Congress today for a lunch with the Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, Bishop Michael Curry. We had an informative conversation about how religion can unite us.

I voted and spoke in favor of a bill today to help protect our nation's workers, small businesses, and taxpayers from an overreaching and counterproductive regulation. The so-called "blacklisting" rule would require federal contractors to disclose even alleged violations of wrongdoing, regardless of whether or not there is any credibility to the claims. This regulation ‚Äì due to the price of compliance ‚Äì could force small and medium sized businesses, who can‚Äôt afford to hire a massive legal team, out of being able to get contracts with the federal government. We should be in the business of supporting policies to make it easier for these kinds of businesses to get new work, not harder. I'm pleased the bill passed by a vote of 236 to 187.

You should all check out this heartwarming story about Foley native and Atlanta Falcons star Julio Jones. As he prepares for the Super Bowl this weekend, this story offers an important reminder about what matters most in life.

We got yet another example yesterday of the need to #BuildTheBridge. Unfortunately, as more and more time goes by, the problems on I-10 just seem to get worse and worse. We have a strong team of local, state, and national officials ready to get this done, and the time for action is now.

I am proud to partner with Congressman Steve Womack to introduce a Constitutional amendment allowing Congress to pass legislation to protect the U.S flag. Courts have blocked efforts by states to ban flag desecration, but this amendment would affirm Congressional authority to protect our nation's most sacred symbol. #ProtectOurÌ†ºÌ∑∫Ì†ºÌ∑∏

The House is focused on using the Congressional Review Act process to roll back government regulations. This is a special process, created by law in 1996, that allows Congress to review rules and overturn harmful ones issued by federal agencies. The best thing about the CRA is that it allows legislation to be considered through an expedited process limiting the ability of the minority to slow and delay the bill. The American people spoke loud and clear in November that they want a federal government that gets out of their way. Through the Congressional Review Act, we are doing just that and allowing the American spirit to flourish.

I filmed a short video to lend my support to Foley's Julio Jones ahead of today's big Super Bowl matchup between the Atlanta Falcons and the New England Patriots. I'm pulling for Julio and the Falcons! What about you?
This ad from Hyundai really helped put the entire game in perspective. Thanks to all those who serve!
Did you know that President Ronald Reagan was born on this day in 1911? May his optimism and steadfast belief in the American spirit continue to guide us.

The search continues for two individuals wanted in connection with a string of murders and crime along the Gulf Coast. If you have any information about either of these individuals or if you spot them, please call 911 immediately. Police officials expect they are armed and dangerous, so they should not be approached. Be sure to share and help spread the word.

Do you support term limits? I do, and I recently co-sponsored a bill to establish term limits for both members of the House and the Senate. Seats in Congress are owned by the people, not the elected officials. Our Founding Fathers never expected individuals to make a career out of Congressional service, and term limits will allow us to keep fresh blood and ideas in the halls of Congress.

It has been a busy day here in Washington, but glad I was able to spend some time with the team from the Mobile County Water, Sewer, and Fire Protection Authority. Their water was recently named the "Best Tasting Water in the State of Alabama" by the Alabama Rural Water Association. Congratulations!
Glad the manhunt appears to be over. Please join me in sharing our appreciation to the local, state, and federal law enforcement officials involved in bringing this search to an end.

Today the House passed two bills designed to roll back federal intervention in education policy. I have spent much of my career working on education issues, and I can personally attest that federal red tape and mandates only make things harder on our teachers and administrators. We should be empowering local school boards, teachers, administrators, and parents because they know our students best. We must limit the role of faceless federal bureaucrats. I spoke in favor of the two bills today on the House floor.

I met this morning with representatives from USA Children's & Women's Hospital to talk about the important work they do in Southwest Alabama and across the Gulf Coast. We are fortunate to have them in our area.

Congratulations to the entire team at the UTC Aerospace Systems facility in Foley on being named one of IndustryWeek's 2016 Best Plants in North America! We are proud to have UTC Aerospace in Baldwin County and even prouder of the great work they do.

Thanks to the crew from the Alabama Rural Health Association for stopping by my office today. We discussed the important role rural hospitals play in many of our local communities. As we work through health care reform, we need to ensure that our rural communities have access to medical care.

This week, the House has focused on continuing to rollback unnecessary and burdensome federal regulations. This includes blocking regulations that would have given more control to the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) over land in the west and given the federal government a larger role in education policy. We need federal bureaucrats to get out of the way, not make things harder.
What a great scene! Jeff Sessions has been officially sworn in as our nation's Attorney General. A truly special day for Alabama and the entire country.

On this day in 1971, Mobilian Satchel Paige was nominated to the Baseball Hall of Fame. He is known for his impressive baseball career, but also for his great sense of humor. Take this quote for example: "Don‚Äôt look back. Something might be gaining on you.‚Äù

Errical Bryant has been "the face" of Alabama's First Congressional District for almost fifteen years. She worked under both Jo Bonner and Sonny Callahan before joining my staff as Director of Operations. As she leaves to begin a new chapter working for Attorney General Jeff Sessions at the Department of Justice, I hope you will join me in thanking her for her years of dedicated service to the people of Southwest Alabama.

Obamacare has resulted in a bunch of broken promises. From being able to keep your doctor to promises of lower costs, far too many Americans are struggling under this broken law. That is why I am committed to repealing the law and instead moving forward with patient-centered health care reforms. This is crucially important to so many American families, and we must do better.
As we get ready for the Conde Cavaliers parade tonight in Mobile, my Washington, D.C. office is also getting in the Mardi Gras spirit! Who else is ready for parade season?

Today is the final day for Martha Lushington as an intern in my Washington, D.C. office. Martha is a graduate of the University of Alabama, and she has been a fantastic member of our team over the last few weeks. I wish her all the best!

On this day in 1809, President Abraham Lincoln was born. One of our most memorable leaders, President Lincoln successfully guided our nation through a period of great conflict and challenges. He will be forever remembered and honored for his leadership, vision, and service.

I have absolutely no issue with our nation's immigration enforcement agencies conducting raids to round up criminals who have broken the law. They are simply doing their job and enforcing the laws of our nation.

HAPPENING NOW: I am holding a telephone town hall meeting to listen to your concerns and answer your questions. To join the call, just dial 877-229-8493 and enter access code 112496. I look forward to hearing from you!

Thanks to the over 3,000 people who took part in my telephone town hall tonight. There were a number of questions about issues at the VA, so I wanted to make sure everyone knew that a new VA Secretary was confirmed tonight. I look forward to working with Secretary Shulkin to increase accountability, give veterans greater access to private medical care, and provide first rate service to our veterans.

I wanted to pass along some good news for those in South Mobile County. The U.S. Department of Agriculture recently announced an $80,000 loan to the Grand Bay Water Works Board to update aging equipment. This is good news for our area.

In the House, we are focused on rolling back burdensome and costly regulations left over from the Obama Administration. These are regulations that restrict freedoms, kill jobs, and hold back economic growth. Our focus is on getting Washington and federal bureaucrats out of the way.

Today, I introduced the Full Choice for Veterans Act. This legislation would give any veteran eligible for VA care the ability to seek care from doctors and specialists in their local community instead of being forced to stay in the broken VA bureaucracy. Under the Full Choice for Veterans Act, we will give veterans the choices they need and access to timely medical care. Even more, I think we can actually save taxpayer money by cutting down on the bloated VA bureaucracy. This is a win-win situation, and I look forward to working with my colleagues to advance this legislation.

Today, I led debate in the House on two resolutions designed to protect working families by blocking harmful regulations. The Obama Administration‚Äôs rules would pave the way for government-run IRAs managed by states and certain municipalities. Employees in several states would be forced to automatically enroll in government-run IRAs that are not subject to the important protections currently in the law. This is yet another attempt to force the American people to do something. We have seen the problems caused when the government tries to tell the American people what to do or what the government thinks is best for them. These type of heavy handed policies simply do not work and are counter to the principles are country was founded on.

Here is a behind the scenes look at my interview this afternoon with Local 15 NBC News, WPMI Mobile. We covered a range of topics including my strong support for Israel and the future of the Department of Labor. You can catch the interview tonight!

I believe states should be able drug test people receiving unemployment benefits. What do you think?  The House voted today to overturn a regulation that would limit the ability of states to drug test and revoke unemployment benefits of people on drugs. Drug testing those who receive government assistance makes sense and is the responsible thing to do. The federal government certainly shouldn't be blocking states from doing so.

Did you catch the report on FOX10 News about my bill giving veterans greater access to private medical care in their local community instead of forcing veterans to remain stuck in the broken VA system? My bill, the Full Choice for Veterans Act, would help our veterans receive better and more timely care.

Here's the view from my seat as I chair today's Workforce Protections Subcommittee hearing. This is my first hearing as Chairman, and I look forward to examining the challenges facing today's 21st Century workforce. You can watch the hearing here: https://m.youtube.com/watch?feature=youtu.be&v=T5ZNxY_4VKc

While visiting Arlington National Cemetery yesterday, I was able to check out the memorial for the Tuskegee Airmen. Also known as the Red Tails, this special group of African American military pilots were the first African American military aviators in the Armed Forces. As we celebrate African American History Month, may we reflect on the service and sacrifice of people like the Tuskegee Airmen.

While at Arlington National Cemetery today, I was able to once again watch the changing of the guard. Every American should be able to watch this historic ceremony. The U.S. Army's Honor Guard protects the tomb. The solider on duty, known as a Sentinel, takes 21 steps and pauses for 21 seconds, which is a tribute to the 21-gun salute.

Today we celebrate our Presidents and the history of our nation. As we continue working to perfect our system of government, I am reminded of this quote from President Dwight Eisenhower: "Accomplishment will prove to be a journey, not a destination.‚Äù May we continue on the journey toward a better, stronger America.

I am currently in Singapore as part of a bipartisan Congressional delegation focused on strengthening the partnership between our two countries. Here in Southwest Alabama, we have some unique ties to Singapore. First, VT MAE Aerospace out at Brookley in Mobile is a Singapore company, and I will be able to meet with their leadership during my trip. Second, the Mobile-built Littoral Combat Ships spend time based in Singapore during their time in the Pacific, so I look forward to hearing firsthand how the ships are performing. Finally, there are many strong trading partnerships between the U.S. and Singapore, and I look forward to helping grow those economic ties.
Pleased to hear President Trump condemn vile and hateful attacks on our nation's Jewish community. There is no place for these type of attacks in today's society.

I've held over 75 town hall meetings since being elected to Congress, and I am pleased to announce I will be holding my next town hall meeting in Mobile on March 6th at 5:30 p.m. Mark your calendars, and I look forward to seeing you!

I had the opportunity to visit with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong during my visit to Singapore. We had a productive conversation about ways to further grow the partnerships between our two countries. I presented the Prime Minister with a figurine of Scout from the book "To Kill A Mockingbird."

I wanted to share my thoughts on President Trump's decision to exit the Paris Climate Agreement. I was not for the United States signing it in the first place because I considered it to be a sham on the basis of two facts.    First, each nation got to pick its own goals or targets and as a result many nations targets are far below what they should be doing relative to others.  This penalizes the United States as we have ambitious targets. China, for example, will be allowed to take far longer to meet its targets than we would have been.   Second, there is no enforcement mechanism so there is no real accountability.  Nations acting in good faith like the United States would make the sacrifices and take the economic hit for doing so, while those not acting in good faith can cheat without any consequence.  Like the Iran deal, President Obama blew this negotiation, and I hope Trump forces everyone back to the table to get a better one.   I absolutely agree we must do something about our climate, but this sham of a deal, which took years to put together and cost an exhorbitant amount of money to produce, was just a way for some world leaders to pretend they were solving the issue and have an expensive self congratulatory event.
